Rope  —n. 1 a stout cord made by twisting together strands of hemp, wire, etc. B piece of this. 2 (foll. By of) quantity of onions, pearls, etc. Strung together. 3 (prec. By the) a halter for hanging a person. B execution by hanging. —v. (-ping) 1 fasten, secure, or catch with rope. 2 (usu. Foll. By off, in) enclose with rope. 3 mountaineering connect with or attach to a rope.  know (or learn or show) the ropes know (or learn or show) how to do a thing properly. Rope in persuade to take part. Rope into persuade to take part in (roped into washing up). [old english]

Deli  n. (pl. -s) colloq. Delicatessen shop. [abbreviation]

Tort  n. Law breach of duty (other than under contract) leading to liability for damages.  tortious adj. [latin torqueo tort- twist]

Outshine  v. (-ning; past and past part. -shone) 1 shine brighter than. 2 surpass in excellence etc.

Unoriginal  adj. Lacking originality; derivative.

Financier  n. Capitalist; entrepreneur. [french: related to *finance]

Lichee  var. Of *lychee.

Correct  —adj. 1 true, accurate. 2 proper, in accordance with taste or a standard. —v. 1 set right; amend. 2 mark errors in. 3 substitute a right thing for (a wrong one). 4 a admonish (a person). B punish (a person or fault). 5 counteract (a harmful quality). 6 adjust (an instrument etc.).  correctly adv. Correctness n. Corrector n. [latin rego rect- guide]

Hex  —v. 1 practise witchcraft. 2 bewitch. —n. Magic spell. [german]

Quatrefoil  n. Four-pointed or -leafed figure, esp. As an architectural ornament. [anglo-french quatre four: related to *foil2]

Hullo  var. Of *hello.

Skimp  v. 1 (often followed by on) economize; use a meagre or insufficient amount of, stint. 2 (often foll. By in) supply (a person etc.) Meagrely with food etc. 3 do hastily or carelessly. [cf. *scrimp]

Palaeography  n. (us paleography) the study of ancient writing and documents.  palaeographer n. [french: related to *palaeo-]

Buckram  n. Coarse linen etc. Stiffened with paste etc. [french boquerant]

Sentinel  n. Sentry or lookout. [french from italian]

Bifocal  —adj. Having two focuses, esp. Of a lens with a part for distant and a part for near vision. —n. (in pl.) Bifocal spectacles.

Tress  n. 1 long lock of human (esp. Female) hair. 2 (in pl.) Woman's or girl's head of hair. [french]

Encyclopedia  n. (also -paedia) book, often in a number of volumes, giving information on many subjects, or on many aspects of one subject. [greek egkuklios all-round, paideia education]

Headstall  n. Part of a halter or bridle fitting round a horse's head.

Unquote  v. (as int.) Verbal formula indicating closing quotation marks.

Wrapround  var. Of *wraparound.

Nitro-  comb. Form of or containing nitric acid, nitre, or nitrogen. [greek: related to *nitre]

Blessing  n. 1 invocation of (esp. Divine) favour. 2 grace said at a meal. 3 benefit.

Transform  v. 1 make a thorough or dramatic change in the form, appearance, character, etc., of. 2 change the voltage etc. Of (an alternating current).  transformation n. [latin]

Pestilent  adj. 1 deadly. 2 harmful or morally destructive. 3 colloq. Troublesome, annoying.

Streetwalker  n. Prostitute seeking customers in the street.

Ready  —adj. (-ier, -iest) (usu. Predic.) 1 with preparations complete (dinner is ready). 2 in a fit state. 3 willing, inclined, or resolved (he is always ready to complain). 4 within reach; easily secured (ready source of income). 5 fit for immediate use. 6 immediate, unqualified (found ready acceptance). 7 prompt (is always ready with excuses). 8 (foll. By to + infin.) About to (ready to burst). 9 provided beforehand. —adv. (usu. In comb.) Beforehand; so as not to require doing when the time comes for use etc. (is ready packed; ready-mixed concrete; ready-made family). —n. (pl. -ies) slang (prec. By the) = *ready money. —v. (-ies, -ied) make ready, prepare.  at the ready ready for action. Make ready prepare. [old english]

Corporative  adj. 1 of a corporation. 2 governed by or organized in corporations.

Reduplicate  v. (-ting) 1 make double. 2 repeat. 3 repeat (a letter or syllable or word) exactly or with a slight change (e.g. Hurly-burly, see-saw).  reduplication n.

Vc  abbr. Victoria cross.

Maisonette  n. 1 flat on more than one floor. 2 small house. [french maisonnette diminutive of maison house]

Amour  n. (esp. Secret) love affair. [french, = love]

Hearty  adj. (-ier, -iest) 1 strong, vigorous. 2 (of a meal or appetite) large. 3 warm, friendly.  heartiness n.

Unionize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) organize in or into a trade union.  unionization n.

Schmaltz  n. Colloq. Esp. Us sentimentality, esp. In music, drama, etc.  schmaltzy adj. [yiddish]

Refloat  v. Set (a stranded ship) afloat again.

Pinhead  n. 1 head of a pin. 2 very small thing or spot. 3 colloq. Stupid person.

Inmost  adj. Most inward. [old english]

Refute  v. (-ting) 1 prove the falsity or error of (a statement etc. Or the person advancing it). 2 rebut by argument. 3 deny or contradict (without argument).  refutation n. [latin refuto]

Usage  the use of refute in sense 3 is considered incorrect by some people. It is often confused in this sense with repudiate.

Metabolism  n. All the chemical processes in a living organism producing energy and growth.  metabolic adj. [greek metabole change: related to *meta-, greek ballo throw]

Cutlet  n. 1 neck-chop of mutton or lamb. 2 small piece of veal etc. For frying. 3 flat cake of minced meat or nuts and breadcrumbs etc. [french diminutive from latin costa rib]

Emir  n. (also amir) title of various muslim rulers. [french from arabic 'amir]

Odour  n. (us odor) 1 smell or fragrance. 2 quality or trace (an odour of intolerance). 3 regard, repute (in bad odour).  odorous adj. Odourless adj. [latin odor]

Scarlatina  n. = *scarlet fever. [italian: related to *scarlet]

Dunnock  n. Hedge sparrow. [apparently from *dun]

Foot  —n. (pl. Feet) 1 a part of the leg below the ankle. B part of a sock etc. Covering this. 2 a lowest part of a page, stairs, etc. B end of a bed where the feet rest. C part of a chair, appliance, etc. On which it rests. 3 step, pace, or tread (fleet of foot). 4 (pl. Feet or foot) linear measure of 12 inches (30.48 cm). 5 metrical unit of verse forming part of a line. 6 hist. Infantry. —v. 1 pay (a bill). 2 (usu. As foot it) go or traverse on foot.  feet of clay fundamental weakness in a respected person. Have one's (or both) feet on the ground be practical. Have one foot in the grave be near death or very old. My foot! Int. Expressing strong contradiction. On foot walking. Put one's feet up colloq. Take a rest. Put one's foot down colloq. 1 insist firmly. 2 accelerate a vehicle. Put one's foot in it colloq. Make a tactless blunder. Under one's feet in the way. Under foot on the ground.  footless adj. [old english]

Untidy  adj. (-ier, -iest) not neat or orderly.  untidily adv. Untidiness n.

Wadi  n. (pl. -s) rocky watercourse in n. Africa etc., dry except in the rainy season. [arabic]

Scabious  n. Plant with esp. Blue pincushion-shaped flowers. [medieval latin scabiosa (herba) named as curing scabies]

Bin  n. Large receptacle for rubbish or storage. [old english]

Sovereignty  n. (pl. -ies) 1 supremacy. 2 a self-government. B self-governing state.

Satisfaction  n. 1 satisfying or being satisfied (derived great satisfaction). 2 thing that satisfies (is a great satisfaction to me). 3 (foll. By for) atonement; compensation (demanded satisfaction).

Chesty  adj. (-ier, -iest) colloq. Inclined to or symptomatic of chest disease.  chestily adv. Chestiness n.

Paunch  n. Belly, stomach, esp. When protruding.  paunchy adj. (-ier, -iest). [anglo-french pa(u)nche from latin pantices bowels]

Demure  adj. (demurer, demurest) 1 quiet, reserved; modest. 2 coy.  demurely adv. Demureness n. [french: related to *demur]

Mephistophelean  adj. Fiendish. [mephistopheles, evil spirit to whom faust sold his soul in german legend]

Undergarment  n. Piece of underclothing.

Rivalry  n. (pl. -ies) being rivals; competition.

Gasket  n. Sheet or ring of rubber etc., shaped to seal the junction of metal surfaces. [french garcette]

Prudent  adj. Cautious; politic.  prudence n. Prudently adv. [latin prudens -ent-: related to *provident]

Itself  pron. Emphatic and refl. Form of *it.  be itself see *oneself. By itself see by oneself. In itself viewed in its essential qualities (not in itself a bad thing). [old english: related to *it, *self]

Raoc  abbr. Royal army ordnance corps.

Conjugal  adj. Of marriage or the relationship of husband and wife. [latin conjux consort]

Sweetie  n. Colloq. 1 = *sweet 1. 2 sweetheart.

Consequent  adj. 1 (often foll. By on, upon) following as a result or consequence. 2 logically consistent.

Catalysis  n. (pl. -lyses) acceleration of a chemical reaction by a catalyst. [greek luo set free]

Ichthyology  n. The study of fishes.  ichthyological adj. Ichthyologist n. [greek ikhthus fish]

Quarto  n. (pl. -s) 1 size of a book or page given by folding a sheet of standard size twice to form four leaves. 2 book or sheet of this size. [latin: related to *quart]

Mortician  n. Us undertaker. [latin mors mort- death]

Linguistic  adj. Of language or the study of languages.  linguistically adv.

Essence  n. 1 fundamental nature; inherent characteristics. 2 a extract got by distillation etc. B perfume.  of the essence indispensable. In essence fundamentally. [latin esse be]

Veld  n. (also veldt) s.afr. Open country. [afrikaans: related to *field]

Pensionable  adj. 1 entitled to a pension. 2 (of a service, job, etc.) Entitling an employee to a pension.

Flatten  v. 1 make or become flat. 2 colloq. A humiliate. B knock down.

Rifling  n. Arrangement of grooves on the inside of a gun's barrel.

Ribbed  adj. Having ribs or riblike markings.

Leveler  n. (brit. Leveller) 1 person who advocates the abolition of social distinctions. 2 person or thing that levels.

Gatehouse  n. House standing by or over a gateway, esp. To a large house or park.

Pitta  n. (also pita) flat hollow unleavened bread which can be split and filled. [modern greek, = a kind of cake]

Delimit  v. (-t-) fix the limits or boundary of.  delimitation n. [latin: related to *limit]

Dyspepsia  n. Indigestion.  dyspeptic adj. & n. [greek peptos digested]

Pheromone  n. Substance secreted and released by an animal for detection and response by another usu. Of the same species. [greek phero convey, *hormone]

Sonata  n. Composition for one or two instruments, usu. In three or four movements. [italian, = sounded]

Bicentenary  n. (pl. -ies) 1 two-hundredth anniversary. 2 celebration of this.

Pestilential  adj. 1 of or relating to pestilence. 2 pestilent.

Quell  v. 1 crush or put down (a rebellion etc.). 2 suppress (fear etc.). [old english]

Mountie  n. Colloq. Member of the royal canadian mounted police. [abbreviation]

Mystery  n. (pl. -ies) 1 secret, hidden, or inexplicable matter. 2 secrecy or obscurity. 3 (attrib.) Secret, undisclosed (mystery guest). 4 practice of making a secret of things (engaged in mystery and intrigue). 5 (in full mystery story) fictional work dealing with a puzzling event, esp. A murder. 6 a religious truth divinely revealed. 7 (in pl.) A secret religious rites of the ancient greeks, romans, etc. B archaic eucharist. [greek musterion: related to *mystic]

Epilepsy  n. Nervous disorder with convulsions and often loss of consciousness. [greek lambano take]

Subtitle  —n. 1 secondary or additional title of a book etc. 2 caption on a film etc., esp. Translating dialogue. —v. (-ling) provide with a subtitle or subtitles.

Chicane  —n. 1 artificial barrier or obstacle on a motor racecourse. 2 chicanery. —v. (-ning) archaic 1 use chicanery. 2 (usu. Foll. By into, out of, etc.) Cheat (a person). [french]

Gusto  n. Zest; enjoyment. [latin gustus taste]

Excrete  v. (-ting) (of an animal or plant) expel (waste matter).  excretion n. Excretory adj. [latin cerno cret- sift]

Fatal  adj. 1 causing or ending in death (fatal accident). 2 (often foll. By to) ruinous (fatal mistake). 3 fateful.  fatally adv. [latin: related to *fate]

Sally  (pl. -ies) —n. 1 sudden military charge; sortie. 2 excursion. 3 witticism. —v. (-ies, -ied) 1 (usu. Foll. By out, forth) set out on a walk, journey, etc. 2 (usu. Foll. By out) make a military sally. [french saillie from latin salio leap]

Fracture  —n. Breakage, esp. Of a bone or cartilage. —v. (-ring) cause a fracture in; suffer fracture. [latin: related to *fraction]

Unsubstantial  adj. = *insubstantial.

Tansy  n. (pl. -ies) plant with yellow flowers and aromatic leaves. [greek athanasia immortality]

Banksia  n. Australian evergreen flowering shrub. [banks, name of a naturalist]

Assent  —v. (usu. Foll. By to) 1 express agreement. 2 consent. —n. Consent or approval, esp. Official.  assenter n. [latin sentio think]

Coaming  n. Raised border round a ship's hatches etc. To keep out water. [origin unknown]

-lyte  suffix forming nouns denoting substances that can be decomposed (electrolyte). [greek lutos loosened]

With  prep. Expressing: 1 instrument or means used (cut with a knife). 2 a association or company (lives with his mother; works with shell). B parting of company (dispense with). 3 cause (shiver with fear). 4 possession (man with dark hair; filled with water). 5 circumstances (sleep with the window open). 6 manner (handle with care). 7 agreement (sympathize with). 8 disagreement, antagonism (incompatible with; quarrel with). 9 understanding (are you with me?). 10 reference or regard (be patient with them; how are things with you?).  away (or in or out etc.) With (as int.) Take, send, or put (a person or thing) away (or in or out etc.). With it colloq. 1 up to date. 2 alert and comprehending. With that thereupon. [old english]

Extremity  n. (pl. -ies) 1 extreme point; very end. 2 (in pl.) The hands and feet. 3 condition of extreme adversity. [latin: related to *extreme]

Menses  n.pl. Flow of menstrual blood etc. [latin, pl. Of mensis month]

Rumpus  n. Colloq. Disturbance, brawl, row, or uproar. [origin unknown]

Bridegroom  n. Man on his wedding day and during the period just before and after it. [old english]

Macroscopic  adj. 1 visible to the naked eye. 2 regarded in terms of large units.

Slain  past part. Of *slay.

Artificer  n. 1 craftsman. 2 skilled military mechanic.

Pundit  n. 1 (also pandit) learned hindu. 2 often iron. Expert.  punditry n. [hindustani from sanskrit]

Incontrovertible  adj. Indisputable, undeniable.  incontrovertibly adv.

Spinnaker  n. Large triangular sail opposite the mainsail of a racing-yacht. [sphinx, name of the yacht first using it]

Parabola  n. Open plane curve formed by the intersection of a cone with a plane parallel to its side.  parabolic adj. [greek parabole placing side by side: related to *parable]

Backyard  n. Yard behind a house etc.

Glory  —n. (pl. -ies) 1 renown, fame; honour. 2 adoring praise. 3 resplendent majesty, beauty, etc. 4 thing that brings renown, distinction, or pride. 5 heavenly bliss and splendour. 6 colloq. State of exaltation, prosperity, etc. 7 halo of a saint etc. —v. (-ies, -ied) (often foll. By in) pride oneself. [latin gloria]

Demilitarize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) remove an army etc. From (a frontier, zone, etc.).  demilitarization n.

Stipendiary  —adj. Receiving a stipend. —n. (pl. -ies) person receiving a stipend. [latin: related to *stipend]

Jack  —n. 1 device for raising heavy objects, esp. Vehicles. 2 court-card with a picture of a soldier, page, etc. 3 ship's flag, esp. Showing nationality. 4 device using a single-pronged plug to connect an electrical circuit. 5 small white target ball in bowls. 6 a = *jackstone. B (in pl.) Game of jackstones. 7 (jack) familiar form of john, esp. Typifying the common man, male animal, etc. (i'm all right, jack). —v. (usu. Foll. By up) 1 raise with or as with a jack (in sense 1). 2 colloq. Raise (e.g. Prices).  every man jack every person. Jack in slang abandon (an attempt etc.). [familiar form of the name john]

Afrikaans  n. Language derived from dutch, used in s. Africa. [dutch, = ‘african’]

Firsthand  adj. & adv. From the original source; direct.

Pterodactyl  n. Large extinct flying reptile. [greek pteron wing, *dactyl]

Psycho  colloq. —n. (pl. -s) psychopath. —adj. Psychopathic. [abbreviation]

Atypical  adj. Not typical.  atypically adv.

Inlet  n. 1 small arm of the sea, a lake, or a river. 2 piece inserted. 3 way of entry. [from *in, *let1]

Sheriff  n. 1 a (also high sheriff) chief executive officer of the crown in a county, administering justice etc. B honorary officer elected annually in some towns. 2 us elected chief law-enforcing officer in a county. 3 (also sheriff-depute) scot. Chief judge of a county or district. [old english: related to *shire, *reeve1]

Latex  n. (pl. -xes) 1 milky fluid of esp. The rubber tree. 2 synthetic product resembling this. [latin, = liquid]

Mend  —v. 1 restore to good condition; repair. 2 regain health. 3 improve (mend matters). —n. Darn or repair in material etc.  mend one's ways reform oneself. On the mend recovering, esp. In health. [anglo-french: related to *amend]

Nice  adj. 1 pleasant, satisfactory. 2 (of a person) kind, good-natured. 3 iron. Bad or awkward (nice mess). 4 fine or subtle (nice distinction). 5 fastidious; delicately sensitive. 6 (foll. By an adj., often with and) satisfactory in terms of the quality described (a nice long time; nice and warm).  nicely adv. Niceness n. Nicish adj. (also niceish). [originally = foolish, from latin nescius ignorant]

Octogenarian  n. Person from 80 to 89 years old. [latin octogeni 80 each]

Aimless  adj. Without aim or purpose.  aimlessly adv.

Usage  the use of ain't is usually regarded as unacceptable in spoken and written english.

Gumboot  n. Rubber boot.

Mizen  n. (also mizzen) (in full mizen-sail) lowest fore-and-aft sail of a fully rigged ship's mizen-mast. [italian: related to *mezzanine]

Unquestioning  adj. 1 asking no questions. 2 (of obedience etc.) Absolute.  unquestioningly adv.

Clavicle  n. Collar-bone. [latin clavis key]

Sleaze  n. Colloq. Sleaziness. [back-formation from *sleazy]

Unsuitable  adj. Not suitable.  unsuitability n. Unsuitably adv.

Messeigneurs  pl. Of *monseigneur.

Quintet  n. 1 mus. A composition for five performers. B the performers. 2 any group of five. [latin quintus]

Commissioner  n. 1 person appointed by a commission to perform a specific task, e.g. The head of the london police etc. 2 member of a government commission. 3 representative of government in a district, department, etc. [medieval latin: related to *commission]

Breeding  n. 1 raising of offspring; propagation. 2 social behaviour; ancestry.

Carsick  adj. Nauseous from car travel.  carsickness n.

Ganger  n. Foreman of a gang of workers.

Respective  adj. Of or relating to each of several individually (go to your respective seats). [french or medieval latin: related to *respect]

Sensationalism  n. Use of or interest in the sensational.  sensationalist n. & adj.

Pastor  n. Minister, esp. Of a nonconformist church. [latin pasco past- feed]

Optimum  —n. (pl. Optima) 1 most favourable conditions (for growth etc.). 2 best practical solution. —adj. = *optimal. [latin, neuter of optimus best]

Incline  —v. (-ning) 1 (usu. In passive) a dispose or influence (am inclined to think so; does not incline me to agree; don't feel inclined). B have a specified tendency (the door is inclined to bang). 2 a be disposed (i incline to think so). B (often foll. By to, towards) tend. 3 (cause to) lean, usu. From the vertical; slope. 4 bend forward or downward. —n. Slope.  incline one's ear listen favourably. [latin clino bend]

Steak  n. 1 thick slice of meat (esp. Beef) or fish, usu. Grilled or fried. 2 beef cut for stewing or braising. [old norse]

Rebellion  n. Open resistance to authority, esp. Organized armed resistance to an established government. [latin: related to *rebel]

Alphabet  n. 1 set of letters used in writing a language. 2 symbols or signs for these.  alphabetical adj. [greek *alpha, *beta]

Thunder  —n. 1 loud noise caused by lightning and due to the expansion of rapidly heated air. 2 resounding loud deep noise (thunders of applause). 3 strong censure or denunciation. —v. 1  (prec. By it as subject) thunder sounds (it is thundering; if it thunders). 2 make or proceed with a noise like thunder. 3 utter (threats, compliments, etc.) Loudly. 4 (foll. By against etc.) Make violent threats etc. Against.  steal a person's thunder see *steal.  thundery adj. [old english]

Erode  v. (-ding) wear away, destroy gradually.  erosion n. Erosive adj. [latin rodo ros- gnaw]

Usher  —n. 1 person who shows people to their seats in a cinema, church, etc. 2 doorkeeper at a court etc. —v. 1 act as usher to. 2 (usu. Foll. By in) announce, herald, or show in. [latin ostium door]

Highlight  —n. 1 moment or detail of vivid interest; outstanding feature. 2 (in a painting etc.) Bright area. 3 (usu. In pl.) Light streak in the hair produced by bleaching. —v. 1 bring into prominence; draw attention to. 2 mark with a highlighter.

Businesslike  adj. Efficient, systematic.

Exam  n. = *examination 3.

Claustrophobia  n. Abnormal fear of confined places.  claustrophobic adj. [latin claustrum *cloister, *-phobia]

Shebeen  n. Esp. Ir. Unlicensed drinking place. [irish]

Ochre  n. (us ocher) 1 earth used as yellow, brown, or red pigment. 2 pale brownish-yellow colour.  ochreous adj. [greek okhra]

Dexterous  adj. (also dextrous) having or showing dexterity.  dexterously adv. Dexterousness n.

Pizzeria  n. Pizza restaurant.

Conjugate  —v. (-ting) 1 gram. List the different forms of (a verb). 2 a unite. B become fused. —adj. 1 joined together, paired. 2 fused. [latin jugum yoke]

Sinecure  n. Profitable or prestigious position requiring little or no work. [latin sine cura without care]

Hypersensitive  adj. Excessively sensitive.  hypersensitivity n.

Obsolete  adj. No longer used, antiquated.

Perambulate  v. (-ting) 1 walk through, over, or about (streets, the country, etc.). 2 walk from place to place.  perambulation n. [latin perambulo: related to *amble]

Emu  abbr. Economic and monetary union; european monetary union.

Warpath  n.  on the warpath 1 (of n. American indians) going to war. 2 colloq. Seeking a confrontation.

Braid  —n. 1 woven band as edging or trimming. 2 us plait of hair. —v. 1 us plait. 2 trim with braid.  braiding n. [old english]

Veal  n. Calf's flesh as food. [french from latin vitulus calf]

Operate  v. (-ting) 1 work, control. 2 be in action; function. 3 a perform a surgical operation. B conduct a military etc. Action. C be active in business etc. 4 bring about. [latin operor work: related to *opus]

Autopsy  n. (pl. -ies) post-mortem. [greek autoptes eye-witness]

Remarkable  adj. Worth notice; exceptional; striking.  remarkably adv. [french remarquable: related to *remark]

Routine  —n. 1 regular course or procedure, unvarying performance of certain acts. 2 set sequence in a dance, comedy act, etc. 3 computing sequence of instructions for a particular task. —adj. 1 performed as part of a routine (routine duties). 2 of a customary or standard kind.  routinely adv. [french: related to *route]

Liquidate  v. (-ting) 1 wind up the affairs of (a firm) by ascertaining liabilities and apportioning assets. 2 pay off (a debt). 3 wipe out, kill.  liquidator n. [medieval latin: related to *liquid]

Arsenic  —n. 1 non-scientific name for arsenic trioxide, a highly poisonous white powder used in weed-killers etc. 2 chem. Brittle semi-metallic element. —adj. Of or containing arsenic. [french, ultimately from persian zar gold]

Visitation  n. 1 official visit of inspection. 2 trouble etc. Seen as divine punishment. 3 (visitation) a visit of the virgin mary to elizabeth. B festival of this.

Unemphatic  adj. Not emphatic.

Appetizer  n. (also -iser) small amount, esp. Of food or drink, to stimulate the appetite.

Swath  n. (also swathe) (pl. -s) 1 ridge of cut grass or corn etc. 2 space left clear by a mower etc. 3 broad strip. [old english]

Jungian  —adj. Of the swiss psychologist carl jung or his theories. —n. Supporter of jung or of his theories.

Tideway  n. Tidal part of a river.

Hellenism  n. (esp. Ancient) greek character or culture.  hellenist n.

Disputation  n. 1 debate, esp. Formal. 2 argument; controversy.

Aphis  n. (pl. Aphides) aphid. [invented by linnaeus: perhaps a misreading of greek koris bug]

Anticipate  v. (-ting) 1 deal with or use before the proper time. 2 expect, foresee (did not anticipate a problem). 3 forestall (a person or thing). 4 look forward to.  anticipation n. Anticipatory adj. [latin anti- before, capio take]

Usage  the use of anticipate in sense 2, ‘expect’, ‘foresee’, is well-established in informal use, but is regarded as incorrect by some people.

Indelicate  adj. 1 coarse, unrefined. 2 tactless.  indelicacy n. (pl. -ies). Indelicately adv.

Pastry  n. (pl. -ies) 1 dough of flour, fat, and water used as a base and covering for pies etc. 2 cake etc. Made wholly or partly of this. [from *paste]

Fringe  —n. 1 border of tassels or loose threads. 2 front hair hanging over the forehead. 3 outer limit of an area, population, etc. (often attrib.: fringe theatre). 4 unimportant area or part. —v. (-ging) 1 adorn with a fringe. 2 serve as a fringe to. [latin fimbria]

Joss  n. Chinese idol. [ultimately from latin deus god]

Came  past of *come.

Grimace  —n. Distortion of the face made in disgust etc. Or to amuse. —v. (-cing) make a grimace. [french from spanish]

Anesthesia  n. (brit. Anaes-) absence of sensation, esp. Artificially induced before surgery. [greek]

Servery  n. (pl. -ies) room or counter from which meals etc. Are served.

Cram  v. (-mm-) 1 a fill to bursting; stuff. B (foll. By in, into; also absol.) Force (a thing) in or into. 2 prepare intensively for an examination. 3 (often foll. By with) feed to excess. [old english]

Cane  —n. 1 a hollow jointed stem of giant reeds or grasses. B solid stem of slender palms. 2 = *sugar cane. 3 cane used for wickerwork etc. 4 cane used as a walking-stick, plant support, for punishment, etc. —v. (-ning) 1 beat with a cane. 2 weave cane into (a chair etc.). [greek kanna reed]

Chill  —n. 1 a unpleasant cold sensation; lowered body temperature. B feverish cold. 2 unpleasant coldness (of air, water, etc.). 3 depressing influence. 4 coldness of manner. —v. 1 make or become cold. 2 depress; horrify. 3 preserve (food or drink) by cooling. —adj. Literary chilly. [old english]

Seduction  n. 1 seducing or being seduced. 2 thing that tempts or attracts.

Spangle  —n. Small piece of glittering material, esp. One of many used to ornament a dress etc.; sequin. —v. (-ling) (esp. As spangled adj.) Cover with or as with spangles (star-spangled). [obsolete spang from dutch]

Anthropology  n. The study of mankind, esp. Its societies and customs.  anthropological adj. Anthropologist n.

Prism  n. 1 solid figure whose two ends are equal parallel rectilinear figures, and whose sides are parallelograms. 2 transparent body in this form, usu. Triangular with refracting surfaces at an acute angle with each other, which separates white light into a spectrum of colours. [greek prisma -mat- thing sawn]

Repaid  past and past part. Of *repay.

Desirable  adj. 1 worth having or doing. 2 sexually attractive.  desirability n. Desirableness n. Desirably adv.

Typhoon  n. Violent hurricane in e. Asian seas. [chinese, = great wind, and arabic]

Halal  n. (also hallal) (often attrib.) Meat from an animal killed according to muslim law. [arabic]

Quod  n.  Slang prison. [origin unknown]

Privy  —adj. 1 (foll. By to) sharing in the secret of (a person's plans etc.). 2 archaic hidden, secret. —n. (pl. -ies) lavatory, esp. An outside one. [french privé private place]

Lobelia  n. Plant with bright, esp. Blue, flowers. [lobel, name of a botanist]

Execrable  adj. Abominable. [latin: related to *execrate]

Hymnology  n. (pl. -ies) 1 the composition or study of hymns. 2 hymns collectively.  hymnologist n.

Multitudinous  adj. 1 very numerous. 2 consisting of many individuals. [latin: related to *multitude]

Mohammedan  var. Of *muhammadan.

Turbot  n. (pl. Same or -s) large european flat-fish prized as food. [french from swedish]

Endpaper  n. Either of the blank leaves of paper at the beginning and end of a book.

Slosh  —v. 1 (often foll. By about) splash or flounder. 2 slang hit, esp. Heavily. 3 colloq. A pour (liquid) clumsily. B pour liquid on. —n. 1 slush. 2 act or sound of splashing. 3 slang heavy blow. [var. Of *slush]

Carrion  n. 1 dead putrefying flesh. 2 something vile or filthy. [latin caro flesh]

Defunct  adj. 1 no longer existing or used. 2 dead or extinct.  defunctness n. [latin fungor perform]

Authority  n. (pl. -ies) 1 a power or right to enforce obedience. B (often foll. By for, or to + infin.) Delegated power. 2 (esp. In pl.) Body having authority. 3 influence based on recognized knowledge or expertise. 4 expert. [latin auctoritas]

Rector  n. 1 (in the church of england) incumbent of a parish where all tithes formerly passed to the incumbent (cf. *vicar). 2 rc ch. Priest in charge of a church or religious institution. 3 head of some universities and colleges.  rectorship n. [latin rego rect- rule]

Unexceptionable  adj. Entirely satisfactory.

Usage  see note at exceptionable.

Ratbag  n. Slang obnoxious person.

Nightshade  n. Any of various plants with poisonous berries. [old english]

Toxicology  n. The study of poisons.  toxicological adj. Toxicologist n.

Meat  n. 1 animal flesh as food. 2 (often foll. By of) substance; chief part.  meatless adj. [old english]

Pagan  —n. Non-religious person, pantheist, or heathen, esp. In pre-christian times. —adj. 1 a of pagans. B irreligious. 2 pantheistic.  paganism n. [latin paganus from pagus country district]

Namesake  n. Person or thing having the same name as another. [probably from for the name's sake]

Jeremiah  n. Dismal prophet, denouncer of the times. [lamentations of jeremiah, in the old testament]

Foment  v. Instigate or stir up (trouble, discontent, etc.).  fomentation n. [latin foveo heat, cherish]

Anthropomorphous  adj. Human in form.

Mulch  —n. Layer of wet straw, leaves, or plastic, etc., spread around or over a plant to enrich or insulate the soil. —v. Treat with mulch. [old english, = soft]

Premeditate  v. (-ting) think out or plan beforehand (premeditated murder).  premeditation n. [latin: related to *meditate]

En  n. Printing unit of measurement equal to half an em. [name of the letter n]

Prominent  adj. 1 jutting out, projecting. 2 conspicuous. 3 distinguished, important. [latin promineo project]

Innuit  var. Of *inuit.

Transfix  v. 1 paralyse with horror or astonishment. 2 pierce with a sharp implement or weapon. [latin: related to *fix]

Sawfish  n. (pl. Same or -es) large marine fish with a toothed flat snout.

Shekel  n. 1 chief monetary unit of modern israel. 2 hist. Silver coin and unit of weight in ancient israel etc. 3 (in pl.) Colloq. Money; riches. [hebrew]

Piste  n. Ski-run of compacted snow. [french, = racetrack]

Untouched  adj. 1 not touched. 2 not affected physically, emotionally, etc. 3 not discussed.

Douse  v. (also dowse) (-sing) 1 a throw water over. B plunge into water. 2 extinguish (a light). [origin uncertain]

Salon  n. 1 room or establishment of a hairdresser, beautician, etc. 2 hist. Meeting of eminent people in the home of a lady of fashion. 3 reception room, esp. Of a continental house. [french: related to *saloon]

Workmanlike  adj. Competent, showing practised skill.

Dotard  n. Senile person.

Enthrone  v. (-ning) place on a throne, esp. Ceremonially.  enthronement n.

Septicaemia  n. (us septicemia) blood-poisoning.  septicaemic adj. [from *septic, greek haima blood]

Shelf  n. (pl. Shelves) 1 wooden etc. Board projecting from a wall, or as part of a unit, used to store things. 2 a projecting horizontal ledge in a cliff face etc. B reef or sandbank.  on the shelf 1 (of a woman) regarded as too old to hope for marriage. 2 (esp. Of a retired person) put aside as if no longer useful. [low german]

Descend  v. 1 go or come down. 2 sink, fall. 3 slope downwards. 4 (usu. Foll. By on) make a sudden attack or visit. 5 (of property etc.) Be passed on by inheritance. 6 a sink in rank, quality, etc. B (foll. By to) stoop to (an unworthy act).  be descended from have as an ancestor.  descendent adj. [latin scando climb]

Principle  n. 1 fundamental truth or law as the basis of reasoning or action. 2 a personal code of conduct (person of high principle). B (in pl.) Personal rules of conduct (has no principles). 3 general law in physics etc. 4 law of nature forming the basis for the construction or working of a machine etc. 5 fundamental source; primary element.  in principle in theory. On principle on the basis of a moral attitude. [latin principium source]

Amend  v. 1 make minor alterations in to improve. 2 correct an error in (a document etc.). [latin: related to *emend]

Usage  amend is often confused with emend, a more technical word used in the context of textual correction.

Macroeconomics  n. The study of the economy as a whole.  macroeconomic adj.

Oil  —n. 1 any of various viscous, usu. Inflammable liquids insoluble in water (cooking oil; drill for oil). 2 petroleum. 3 (in comb.) Using oil as fuel (oil-heater). 4 a (usu. In pl.) = *oil-paint. B picture painted in oil-paints. —v. 1 apply oil to; lubricate. 2 impregnate or treat with oil (oiled silk).  oil the wheels help make things go smoothly. [latin oleum olive oil]

Hardcore  n. Solid material, esp. Rubble, as road-foundation.

Poesy  n. Archaic poetry. [french, ultimately as *poem]

Neoclassicism  n. Revival of classical style or treatment in the arts.  neoclassical adj.

Twenty  adj. & n. (pl. -ies) 1 product of two and ten. 2 symbol for this (20, xx, xx). 3 (in pl.) Numbers from 20 to 29, esp. The years of a century or of a person's life.  twentieth adj. & n. [old english]

Barley  n. 1 cereal used as food and in spirits. 2 (also barleycorn) its grain. [old english]

Antagonist  n. Opponent or adversary.  antagonistic adj.

Recriminate  v. (-ting) make mutual or counter accusations.  recrimination n. Recriminatory adj. [medieval latin: related to *crime]

Publish  v. 1 (also absol.) Prepare and issue (a book, newspaper, etc.) For public sale. 2 make generally known. 3 announce formally. [latin: related to *public]

Insured  n. (usu. Prec. By the) person etc. Covered by insurance.

Flicker  —v. 1 (of light or flame) shine or burn unsteadily. 2 flutter. 3 (of hope etc.) Waver. —n. 1 flickering movement or light. 2 brief spell (of hope etc.).  flicker out die away. [old english]

Part  —n. 1 some but not all of a thing or group of things. 2 essential member, constituent, or component (part of the family; spare parts). 3 portion of a human or animal body. 4 division of a book, broadcast serial, etc., esp. Issued or broadcast at one time. 5 each of several equal portions of a whole (3 parts sugar to 2 parts flour). 6 a allotted share. B person's share in an action etc. (had no part in it). C duty (not my part to interfere). 7 a character assigned to, or words spoken by, an actor on stage. B melody etc. Assigned to a particular voice or instrument. C printed or written copy of an actor's or musician's part. 8 side in an agreement or dispute. 9 (in pl.) Region or district (am not from these parts). 10 (in pl.) Abilities (man of many parts). —v. 1 divide or separate into parts (crowd parted). 2 a leave one another's company (parted the best of friends). B (foll. By from) say goodbye to. 3 (foll. By with) give up; hand over. 4 separate (hair of the head) to make a parting. —adv. In part; partly (part iron and part wood).  for the most part see *most. For one's part as far as one is concerned. In part (or parts) partly. On the part of made or done by (no objection on my part). Part and parcel (usu. Foll. By of) an essential part. Part company see *company. Play a part 1 be significant or contributory. 2 act deceitfully. 3 perform a theatrical role. Take in good part not be offended by. Take part (often foll. By in) assist or have a share (in). Take the part of support; side with. [latin pars part-]

Dual  —adj. 1 in two parts; twofold. 2 double (dual ownership). —n. Gram. Dual number or form.  duality n. [latin duo two]

Golden  adj. 1 a made or consisting of gold. B yielding gold. 2 coloured or shining like gold (golden hair). 3 precious; excellent.

Polyurethane  n. Synthetic resin or plastic used esp. In paints or foam. [related to *urea, *ethane]

Cab  n. 1 taxi. 2 driver's compartment in a lorry, train, or crane etc. [abbreviation of *cabriolet]

Plague  —n. 1 deadly contagious disease. 2 (foll. By of) colloq. Infestation of a pest etc. 3 great trouble or affliction. 4 colloq. Nuisance. —v. (plagues, plagued, plaguing) 1 colloq. Pester, annoy. 2 afflict, hinder (plagued by back pain). 3 affect with plague. [latin plaga stroke, infection]

Insistent  adj. 1 (often foll. By on) insisting. 2 forcing itself on the attention.  insistence n. Insistently adv.

Adhesive  —adj. Sticky, causing adhesion. —n. Adhesive substance.  adhesiveness n.

Tripper  n. Person who goes on a pleasure trip.

Teach  v. (past and past part. Taught) 1 a give systematic information, instruction, or training to (a person) or about (a subject or skill) (taught me to swim). B (absol.) Practise this professionally. C communicate, instruct in (suffering taught me patience). 2 advocate as a moral etc. Principle (taught forgiveness). 3 (foll. By to + infin.) A instruct (a person) by example or punishment (that will teach you not to disobey). B colloq. Discourage (a person) from (that will teach you to laugh).  teachable adj. [old english]

Theosophy  n. (pl. -ies) any of various philosophies professing to achieve knowledge of god by spiritual ecstasy, direct intuition, or special individual relations, esp. A modern movement following hindu and buddhist teachings and seeking universal brotherhood.  theosophical adj. Theosophist n. [greek theosophos wise concerning god]

Darky  n. (also darkie) (pl. -ies) slang offens. Black person.

Tug  —v. (-gg-) 1 (often foll. By at) pull hard or violently; jerk. 2 tow (a ship etc.) By a tugboat. —n. 1 hard, violent, or jerky pull. 2 sudden strong emotion. 3 small powerful boat for towing ships. [related to *tow1]

Tribune  n. 1 popular leader or demagogue. 2 (in full tribune of the people) official in ancient rome chosen by the people to protect their interests. [latin tribunus: related to *tribe]

Pliable  adj. 1 bending easily; supple. 2 yielding, compliant.  pliability n. [french: related to *ply1]

Buttress  —n. 1 projecting support built against a wall. 2 source of help etc. —v. (often foll. By up) 1 support with a buttress. 2 support by argument etc. (buttressed by facts). [related to *butt1]

Doge  n. Hist. Chief magistrate of venice or genoa. [italian from latin dux leader]

Amaranth  n. 1 plant with small green, red, or purple tinted flowers. 2 imaginary unfading flower. 3 purple colour.  amaranthine adj. [greek amarantos unfading]

Cohesion  n. 1 a sticking together. B tendency to cohere. 2 chem. Force with which molecules cohere.  cohesive adj.

Overprint  —v. Print over (a surface already printed). —n. Words etc. Overprinted.

Meeting  n. 1 coming together. 2 assembly of esp. A society, committee, etc. 3 = *race meeting.

Lift  —v. 1 (often foll. By up, off, out, etc.) Raise or remove to a higher position. 2 go up; be raised; yield to an upward force. 3 give an upward direction to (the eyes or face). 4 elevate to a higher plane of thought or feeling. 5 (of fog etc.) Rise, disperse. 6 remove (a barrier or restriction). 7 transport (supplies, troops, etc.) By air. 8 colloq. A steal. B plagiarize (a passage of writing etc.). 9 dig up (esp. Potatoes etc.). —n. 1 lifting or being lifted. 2 ride in another person's vehicle (gave them a lift).

-ee  suffix forming nouns denoting: 1 person affected by the verbal action (employee; payee). 2 person concerned with or described as (absentee; refugee). 3 object of smaller size (bootee). [french -? in past part.]

Assizes  n.pl. Hist. Court periodically administering the civil and criminal law. [french: related to *assess]

Usage  in 1972 the civil jurisdiction of assizes in england and wales was transferred to the high court and the criminal jurisdiction to the crown court.

Inaction  n. Lack of action.

Mythology  n. (pl. -ies) 1 body of myths. 2 the study of myths.  mythological adj. Mythologize v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing). [greek: related to *myth]

Bootee  n. Baby's soft shoe.

Futile  adj. 1 useless, ineffectual. 2 frivolous.  futility n. [latin futilis leaky, futile]

Inflammatory  adj. 1 tending to cause anger etc. 2 of inflammation.

Despair  —n. 1 complete loss or absence of hope. 2 cause of this. —v. (often foll. By of) lose or be without hope (despaired of ever winning). [latin spero hope]

Armada  n. Fleet of warships, esp. (armada) that sent by spain against england in 1588. [spanish from romanic]

Hardwood  n. Wood from a deciduous broad-leaved tree.

Discourse  —n. 1 conversation. 2 lengthy treatment of a subject. 3 lecture, speech. —v. (-sing) 1 converse. 2 speak or write at length on a subject. [latin curro curs- run]

Assegai  n. (also assagai) light iron-tipped s. African spear. [arabic, = the spear]

Oi  int. Calling attention or expressing alarm etc. [var. Of *hoy]

Enslave  v. (-ving) make (a person) a slave.  enslavement n.

Abstruse  adj. Hard to understand, profound. [latin abstrudo -trus- conceal]

Tine  n. Prong, tooth, or point of a fork, comb, antler, etc. [old english]

Philology  n. The study of language, esp. In its historical and comparative aspects.  philological adj. Philologist n. [french from latin from greek: related to *philo-, *-logy]

Unsocial  adj. 1 not social; not suitable for or seeking society. 2 outside the normal working day (unsocial hours). 3 antisocial.

Usage  unsocial is sometimes confused with unsociable.

Honesty  n. 1 being honest. 2 truthfulness. 3 plant with purple or white flowers and flat round semi-transparent seed-pods.

Perjure  v.refl. (-ring) law 1 wilfully tell a lie when on oath. 2 (as perjured adj.) Guilty of or involving perjury.  perjurer n. [french from latin juro swear]

Venue  n. Place for a match, meeting, concert, etc. [french, from venir come]

Dominican  —adj. Of st dominic or his order. —n. Dominican friar or nun. [latin dominicus dominic]

Time  —n. 1 indefinite continued progress of existence, events, etc., in the past, present, and future, regarded as a whole. 2 progress of this as affecting persons or things. 3 portion of time belonging to particular events or circumstances (the time of the plague; prehistoric times). 4 allotted or available portion of time (had no time to eat). 5 point of time, esp. In hours and minutes (the time is 7.30). 6 (prec. By a) indefinite period. 7 time or an amount of time as reckoned by a conventional standard (eight o'clock new york time; the time allowed is one hour). 8 occasion (last time). 9 moment etc. Suitable for a purpose etc. (the time to act). 10 (in pl.) Expressing multiplication (five times six is thirty). 11 lifetime (will last my time). 12 (in sing. Or pl.) Conditions of life or of a period (hard times). 13 slang prison sentence (is doing time). 14 apprenticeship (served his time). 15 period of gestation. 16 date or expected date of childbirth or death. 17 measured time spent in work. 18 a any of several rhythmic patterns of music. B duration of a note. —v. (-ming) 1 choose the time for. 2 do at a chosen or correct time. 3 arrange the time of arrival of. 4 ascertain the time taken by.  against time with utmost speed, so as to finish by a specified time. Ahead of time earlier than expected. All the time 1 during the whole of the time referred to (often despite some contrary expectation etc.). 2 constantly. At one time 1 in a known but unspecified past period. 2 simultaneously. At the same time 1 simultaneously. 2 nevertheless. At times intermittently. For the time being until some other arrangement is made. Half the time colloq. As often as not. Have no time for 1 be unable or unwilling to spend time on. 2 dislike. Have a time of it undergo trouble or difficulty. In no time 1 very soon. 2 very quickly. In time 1 not late, punctual. 2 eventually. 3 in accordance with a given rhythm. Keep time move or sing etc. In time. Pass the time of day colloq. Exchange a greeting or casual remarks. Time after time 1 on many occasions. 2 in many instances. Time and (or time and time) again on many occasions. The time of one's life period of exceptional enjoyment. Time out of mind a longer time than anyone can remember. Time was there was a time. [old english]

Parole  —n. 1 temporary or permanent release of a prisoner before the expiry of a sentence, on the promise of good behaviour. 2 such a promise. —v. (-ling) put (a prisoner) on parole. [french, = word: related to *parlance]

Aardvark  n. Mammal with a tubular snout and a long tongue, feeding on termites. [afrikaans]

Squirm  —v. 1 wriggle, writhe. 2 show or feel embarrassment. —n. Squirming movement. [imitative]

Stylist  n. 1 a designer of fashionable styles etc. B hairdresser. 2 stylish writer or performer.

Watchmaker  n. Person who makes and repairs watches and clocks.

Centime  n. 1 one-hundredth of a franc. 2 coin of this value. [latin centum 100]

Airship  n. Power-driven aircraft lighter than air.

Tomfoolery  n. Foolish behaviour.

Seaplane  n. Aircraft designed to take off from and land on water.

Playground  n. Outdoor area for children to play in.

Spritsail  n. Sail extended by a sprit.

Peeling  n. (usu. In pl.) Stripped-off piece of peel.

Bursar  n. 1 treasurer, esp. Of a college. 2 holder of a bursary. [medieval latin bursarius from bursa purse]

Precise  adj. 1 a accurately expressed. B definite, exact. 2 punctilious; scrupulous in being exact. [latin praecido cut short]

Conserve  —v. (-ving) keep from harm or damage, esp. For later use. —n. Fresh fruit jam. [latin servo keep]

Cadet  n. Young trainee for the armed services or police force.  cadetship n. [french, ultimately from latin caput head]

Communion  n. 1 sharing, esp. Of thoughts etc.; fellowship. 2 participation; sharing in common (communion of interests). 3 (communion or holy communion) eucharist. 4 body or group within the christian faith (the methodist communion). [latin: related to *common]

Sonic  adj. Of or using sound or sound waves. [latin sonus sound]

Mbo  abbr. Management buyout.

Musician  n. Person who plays a musical instrument, esp. Professionally.  musicianly adj. Musicianship n. [french: related to *music]

Mazurka  n. 1 lively polish dance in triple time. 2 music for this. [french or german from polish]

Since  —prep. Throughout or during the period after (has been here since june; happened since yesterday). —conj. 1 during or in the time after (what have you done since we met?). 2 because. —adv. 1 from that time or event until now (has not seen him since). 2 ago (many years since). [old english, = after that]

Crackers  predic. Adj. Slang crazy.

Cineraria  n. Composite plant with bright flowers and ash-coloured down on its leaves. [latin cinis -ner- ashes]

Leviathan  n. 1 bibl. Sea-monster. 2 very large or powerful thing. [latin from hebrew]

Sanatorium  n. (pl. -s or -ria) 1 residential clinic, esp. For convalescents and the chronically sick. 2 room etc. For sick people in a school etc. [latin sano heal]

Eschatology  n. Theology of death and final destiny.  eschatological adj. [greek eskhatos last]

Gas  —n. (pl. -es) 1 any airlike substance (i.e. Not solid or liquid) moving freely to fill any space available. 2 such a substance (esp. Found naturally or extracted from coal) used as fuel (also attrib.: gas cooker; gas industry). 3 nitrous oxide or other gas as an anaesthetic. 4 poisonous gas used in war. 5 us colloq. Petrol, gasoline. 6 slang idle talk; boasting. 7 slang enjoyable or amusing thing or person. —v. (gases, gassed, gassing) 1 expose to gas, esp. To kill. 2 colloq. Talk idly or boastfully.

Hemorrhage  (brit. Haem-) —n. 1 profuse loss of blood from a ruptured blood-vessel. 2 damaging loss, esp. Of people or assets. —v. (-ging) suffer a haemorrhage. [greek haima blood, rhegnumi burst]

Ago  adv. (prec. By duration) earlier, in the past. [originally agone = gone by]

Justice  n. 1 justness, fairness. 2 authority exercised in the maintenance of right. 3 judicial proceedings (brought to justice; court of justice). 4 magistrate; judge.  do justice to 1 treat fairly. 2 appreciate properly. Do oneself justice perform at one's best. With justice reasonably. [latin justitia]

Eiderdown  n. Quilt stuffed with soft material, esp. Down.

Smoulder  (us smolder) —v. 1 burn slowly without flame or internally. 2 (of emotions) be fierce but suppressed. 3 (of a person) show silent emotion. —n. Smouldering. [origin unknown]

Appro  n. Colloq.  on appro = on approval (see *approval). [abbreviation]

Outage  n. Period during which a power-supply etc. Is not operating.

Considerate  adj. Thoughtful towards others; careful not to cause hurt or inconvenience.  considerately adv. [latin: related to *consider]

Throwback  n. 1 reversion to ancestral character. 2 instance of this.

Friesian  n. One of a breed of black and white dairy cattle orig. From friesland. [var. Of *frisian]

Alternate  —v. (-ting) 1 (often foll. By with) occur or cause to occur by turns. 2 (foll. By between) go repeatedly from one to another (alternated between hope and fear). —adj. 1 (with noun in pl.) Every other (on alternate days). 2 (of things of two kinds) alternating (alternate joy and misery).  alternately adv. Alternation n. [latin alterno do by turns: related to *alter]

Usage  see note at alternative.

Arose  past of *arise.

Lancet  n. Small broad two-edged surgical knife with a sharp point.

Upturn  —n. Upward trend; improvement. —v. Turn up or upside down.

Undervalue  v. (-ues, -ued, -uing) 1 value insufficiently. 2 underestimate.

Crap  coarse slang —n. 1 (often as int. Or attrib.) Nonsense, rubbish. 2 faeces. —v. (-pp-) defecate.  crappy adj. (-ier, -iest). [dutch]

Footling  adj. Colloq. Trivial, silly.

Op  n. Colloq. Operation. [abbreviation]

Midget  n. 1 extremely small person or thing. 2 (attrib.) Very small.

Peaky  adj. (-ier, -iest) 1 sickly; puny. 2 white-faced.

Mawkish  adj. Feebly sentimental; sickly.  mawkishly adv. Mawkishness n. [obsolete mawk *maggot]

Terror  n. 1 extreme fear. 2 a terrifying person or thing. B colloq. Formidable or troublesome person or thing, esp. A child. 3 organized intimidation; terrorism. [latin terreo frighten]

Methodology  n. (pl. -ies) 1 body of methods used in a particular activity. 2 science of method.  methodological adj. Methodologically adv.

Unchain  v. Remove the chain(s) from; release.

Voluble  adj. Speaking or spoken fluently or at length.  volubility n. Volubly adv. [latin volvo roll]

Hexameter  n. Line of verse with six metrical feet.

Dolma  n. (pl. -s or dolmades) e. European delicacy of spiced rice or meat etc. Wrapped in vine or cabbage leaves. [modern greek]

Suspender  n. 1 attachment to hold up a stocking or sock by its top. 2 (in pl.) Us braces.

Veranda  n. (usu. Covered) platform along the side of a house. [hindi from portuguese varanda]

Flavouring  n. (us flavoring) substance used to flavour food or drink.

Odoriferous  adj. Diffusing a (usu. Agreeable) odour. [latin: related to *odour]

Imminent  adj. Impending; about to happen (war is imminent).  imminence n. Imminently adv. [latin immineo be impending]

Championship  n. 1 (often in pl.) Contest to decide the champion in a sport etc. 2 position of champion.

Middleweight  n. 1 weight in certain sports between welterweight and light heavyweight, in amateur boxing 71–5 kg. 2 sportsman of this weight.

Mot  abbr. (in full mot test) compulsory annual test of vehicles of more than a specified age. [ministry of transport]

Discredit  —n. 1 harm to reputation. 2 person or thing causing this. 3 lack of credibility. —v. (-t-) 1 harm the good reputation of. 2 cause to be disbelieved. 3 refuse to believe.

Camomile  n. (also chamomile) aromatic plant with daisy-like flowers used esp. To make tea. [greek, = earth-apple]

Syrian  —n. 1 native or national of syria. 2 person of syrian descent. —adj. Of syria.

Phantasm  n. Illusion, phantom.  phantasmal adj. [latin: related to *phantom]

Spindle  n. 1 slender rod or bar, often tapered, for twisting and winding thread. 2 pin or axis that revolves or on which something revolves. 3 turned piece of wood used as a banister, chair leg, etc. [old english: related to *spin]

Thrive  v. (-ving; past throve or thrived; past part. Thriven or thrived) 1 prosper, flourish. 2 grow rich. 3 (of a child, animal, or plant) grow vigorously. [old norse]

Procrastinate  v. (-ting) defer action.  procrastination n. Procrastinator n. [latin cras tomorrow]

Usage  procrastinate is often confused with prevaricate which means ‘to be evasive, quibble’.

Neutrino  n. (pl. -s) elementary particle with zero electric charge and probably zero mass. [italian, diminutive of neutro neutral: related to *neuter]

Brotherhood  n. 1 relationship between brothers. 2 association of people with a common interest. 3 community of feeling between human beings.

Purpose  —n. 1 object to be attained; thing intended. 2 intention to act. 3 resolution, determination. —v. (-sing) have as one's purpose; design, intend.  on purpose intentionally. To no purpose with no result or effect. To the purpose 1 relevant. 2 useful. [latin propono *propose]

Mishap  n. Unlucky accident.

Global  adj. 1 worldwide (global conflict). 2 all-embracing.  globally adv. [french: related to *globe]

Ewe  n. Female sheep. [old english]

Powerboat  n. Powerful motor boat.

Exeunt  v. (as a stage direction) (actors) leave the stage. [latin: related to *exit]

Bract  n. Leaf-like and often brightly coloured part of a plant, growing before the flower. [latin bractea thin sheet]

Parentage  n. Lineage; descent from or through parents.

Parable  n. 1 story used to illustrate a moral or spiritual lesson. 2 allegory. [greek parabole comparison]

Trichromatic  adj. 1 having or using three colours. 2 (of vision) having the normal three colour-sensations, i.e. Red, green, and purple.

Fba  abbr. Fellow of the british academy.

Brae  n. Scot. Hillside. [old norse]

Codex  n. (pl. Codices) 1 ancient manuscript text in book form. 2 collection of descriptions of drugs etc. [latin, = tablet, book]

Integer  n. Whole number. [latin, = untouched, whole]

Identification  n. 1 identifying. 2 means of identifying (also attrib.: identification card).

Masonic  adj. Of freemasons.

Niobium  n.  Rare metallic element occurring naturally. [niobe in greek legend]

Thereby  adv. By that means, as a result of that.  thereby hangs a tale much could be said about that.

Outlet  n. 1 means of exit or escape. 2 means of expressing feelings. 3 a market for goods. B shop (retail outlet).

Sketch  —n. 1 rough or unfinished drawing or painting. 2 rough draft or general outline. 3 short usu. Humorous play. 4 short descriptive essay etc. —v. 1 make or give a sketch of. 2 draw sketches. 3 (often foll. By in, out) outline briefly. [greek skhedios extempore]

Quill  n. 1 (in full quill-feather) large feather in a wing or tail. 2 hollow stem of this. 3 (in full quill pen) pen made of a quill. 4 (usu. In pl.) Porcupine's spine. [probably low german quiele]

Putative  adj. Formal reputed, supposed (his putative father). [latin puto think]

Married  —adj. 1 united in marriage. 2 of marriage (married name; married life). —n. (usu. In pl.) Married person (young marrieds).

Anemia  n. (brit. Anaemia) deficiency of red blood cells or their haemoglobin, causing pallor and weariness. [greek, = want of blood]

Holism  n. (also wholism) 1 philos. Theory that certain wholes are greater than the sum of their parts. 2 med. Treating of the whole person rather than the symptoms of a disease.  holistic adj. [greek holos whole]

Stoicism  n. 1 philosophy of the stoics. 2 (stoicism) stoical attitude.

Kilocalorie  n. = large calorie (see *calorie).

Indigestion  n. 1 difficulty in digesting food. 2 pain caused by this.

Gynaecology  n. (us gynecology) science of the physiological functions and diseases of women.  gynaecological adj. Gynaecologist n. [greek gune gunaik- woman, *-logy]

Breadth  n. 1 distance or measurement from side to side of a thing. 2 freedom from prejudice or intolerance. [old english: related to *broad]

Kimono  n. (pl. -s) 1 long sashed japanese robe. 2 similar dressing-gown. [japanese]

Regiment  —n. 1 a permanent unit of an army, usu. Commanded by a colonel and divided into several companies, troops, or batteries. B operational unit of artillery etc. 2 (usu. Foll. By of) large or formidable array or number. —v. 1 organize (esp. Oppressively) in groups or according to a system. 2 form into a regiment or regiments.  regimentation n. [latin: related to *regimen]

Pluck  —v. 1 pick or pull out or away. 2 strip (a bird) of feathers. 3 pull at, twitch. 4 (foll. By at) tug or snatch at. 5 sound (the string of a musical instrument) with a finger or plectrum. 6 plunder. —n. 1 courage, spirit. 2 plucking; twitch. 3 animal's heart, liver, and lungs as food.  pluck up summon up (one's courage etc.). [old english]

Hansard  n. Official verbatim record of debates in the british parliament. [hansard, name of its first printer]

Waken  v. Make or become awake. [old norse]

Satanism  n. 1 worship of satan. 2 pursuit of evil.  satanist n. & adj.

Esophagus  n. (brit. Oesophagus) (pl. -gi or -guses) passage from the mouth to the stomach; gullet. [greek]

Portent  n. 1 omen, significant sign of something to come. 2 prodigy; marvellous thing. [latin portentum: related to *portend]

Wally  n. (pl. -ies) slang foolish or inept person. [origin uncertain]

Relentless  adj. Unrelenting, oppressively constant.  relentlessly adv.

Unmodified  adj. Not modified.

Minster  n. 1 large or important church. 2 church of a monastery. [old english: related to *monastery]

Equinoctial  —adj. Happening at or near the time of an equinox. —n. (in full equinoctial line) = *celestial equator. [latin: related to *equinox]

Nook  n. Corner or recess; secluded place. [origin unknown]

Grab  —v. (-bb-) 1 seize suddenly. 2 take greedily or unfairly. 3 slang attract the attention of, impress. 4 (foll. By at) snatch at. 5 (of brakes) act harshly or jerkily. —n. 1 sudden clutch or attempt to seize. 2 mechanical device for clutching. [low german or dutch]

Ordinal  n. (in full ordinal number) number defining position in a series, e.g. ‘first’, ‘second’, ‘third’, etc. [latin: related to *order]

Courtesan  n. Prostitute, esp. One with wealthy or upper-class clients. [italian: related to *court]

Alleviate  v. (-ting) make (pain etc.) Less severe.  alleviation n. [latin levo raise]

Caboose  n. 1 kitchen on a ship's deck. 2 us guard's van on a train etc. [dutch]

Lethargy  n. 1 lack of energy. 2 morbid drowsiness.  lethargic adj. Lethargically adv. [greek lethargos forgetful]

Manned  adj. (of a spacecraft etc.) Having a human crew.

Fiddlesticks  int. Nonsense.

Desensitize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) reduce or destroy the sensitivity of.  desensitization n.

Siege  n. 1 surrounding and blockading of a town, castle, etc. 2 similar operation by police etc. To force an armed person out of a building.  lay siege to conduct the siege of. Raise the siege of abandon, or cause the abandonment of, an attempted siege of. [french sege seat]

Jurassic  geol. —adj. Of the second period of the mesozoic era. —n. This era or system. [french from jura mountains]

Petroleum  n. Hydrocarbon oil found in the upper strata of the earth, refined for use as fuel etc. [latin petra rock, oleum oil]

Desist  v. (often foll. By from) abstain; cease. [latin desisto]

Blasphemy  n. (pl. -ies) 1 irreverent talk or treatment of a religious or sacred thing. 2 instance of this.  blasphemous adj.

Quanta  pl. Of *quantum.

Apposition  n. Juxtaposition, esp. Gram. Of elements sharing a syntactic function (e.g. William the conqueror; my friend sue).

Coin  —n. 1 stamped disc of metal as official money. 2 (collect.) Metal money. —v. 1 make (coins) by stamping. 2 make (metal) into coins. 3 invent (esp. A new word or phrase).  coin money make much money quickly. [latin cuneus wedge]

Photofit  n. Reconstructed picture of a suspect made from composite photographs.

Item  n. 1 any of a number of enumerated things. 2 separate or distinct piece of news etc. [latin, = in like manner]

Chronology  n. (pl. -ies) 1 science of determining dates. 2 a arrangement of events etc. In order of occurrence. B table or document displaying this. [greek khronos time, *-logy]

Loopy  adj. (-ier, -iest) slang crazy, daft.

Omen  —n. 1 event or object portending good or evil. 2 prophetic significance (of good omen). —v. (usu. In passive) portend.  [latin]

Surge  —n. 1 sudden rush. 2 heavy forward or upward motion. 3 sudden increase in price, activity, etc. 4 sudden increase in voltage of an electric current. 5 swell of the sea. —v. (-ging) 1 move suddenly and powerfully forwards. 2 (of an electric current etc.) Increase suddenly. 3 (of the sea etc.) Swell. [latin surgo rise]

Umbilicus  n. (pl. -ci or -cuses) navel. [latin]

Polysaccharide  n. Any of a group of complex carbohydrates, e.g. Starch. [see *saccharin]

Prescribe  v. (-bing) 1 a advise the use of (a medicine etc.). B recommend, esp. As a benefit. 2 lay down or impose authoritatively. [latin praescribo]

Usage  prescribe is sometimes confused with proscribe.

Unfriendly  adj. (-ier, -iest) not friendly; hostile.

Unflappable  adj. Colloq. Imperturbable; calm.  unflappability n.

Mensuration  n. 1 measuring. 2 measuring of lengths, areas, and volumes. [latin: related to *measure]

Stallholder  n. Person in charge of a stall at a market etc.

Outfit  n. 1 set of clothes or equipment. 2 colloq. Group of people regarded as an organization.

Reflective  adj. 1 (of a surface etc.) Reflecting. 2 (of mental faculties) concerned in reflection or thought. 3 (of a person or mood etc.) Thoughtful; given to meditation.  reflectively adv. Reflectiveness n.

Yahoo  n. Bestial person. [name of a race of brutes in gulliver's travels]

Spouse  n. Husband or wife. [latin sponsus sponsa betrothed]

Buckthorn  n. Thorny shrub with berries formerly used as a purgative.

Pitfall  n. 1 unsuspected danger or drawback. 2 covered pit for trapping animals.

Stokehole  n. Space for stokers in front of a furnace.

Bitty  adj. (-ier, -iest) made up of bits; scrappy.

Ruction  n. Colloq. 1 disturbance or tumult. 2 (in pl.) Row, heated arguments. [origin unknown]

Energy  n. (pl. -ies) 1 capacity for activity, force, vigour. 2 capacity of matter or radiation to do work. [greek ergon work]

Downhearted  adj. Dejected.  downheartedly adv. Downheartedness n.

Undersurface  n. Lower or under surface.

Lifestyle  n. Way of life of a person or group.

Cognate  —adj. 1 related to or descended from a common ancestor. 2 (of a word) having the same linguistic family or derivation. —n. 1 relative. 2 cognate word. [latin cognatus]

Acute  —adj. (acuter, acutest) 1 serious, severe (acute hardship). 2 (of senses etc.) Keen, penetrating. 3 shrewd. 4 (of a disease) coming quickly to a crisis. 5 (of an angle) less than 90°. 6 (of a sound) high, shrill. —n. = *acute accent.  acutely adv. [latin acutus pointed]

Oath  n. (pl. -s) 1 solemn declaration naming god etc. As witness. 2 profanity, curse.  on (or under) oath having sworn a solemn oath. [old english]

Monoxide  n. Oxide containing one oxygen atom.

Qualitative  adj. Of quality as opposed to quantity.  qualitatively adv.  [latin: related to *quality]

Indium  n. Soft silvery-white metallic element occurring in zinc ores. [latin indicum *indigo]

Delta  n. 1 triangular area of earth, alluvium etc. At the mouth of a river, formed by its diverging outlets. 2 a fourth letter of the greek alphabet (d, d). B fourth-class mark for work etc. [greek]

Ping  —n. Single short high ringing sound. —v. (cause to) make a ping. [imitative]

Provo  n. (pl. -s) colloq. Provisional. [abbreviation]

Zebu  n. (pl. Same or -s) humped ox of asia and africa. [french]

Gawk  —v. Colloq. Gawp. —n. Awkward or bashful person. [obsolete gaw *gaze]

Misshapen  adj. Ill-shaped, deformed, distorted. [from *mis-1, shapen (archaic) = shaped]

Reticulate  —v. (-ting) divide or be divided in fact or appearance into a network. —adj. Reticulated.  reticulation n. [latin reticulum diminutive of rete net]

Cameraman  n. Person who operates a camera professionally, esp. In film-making or television.

Spikenard  n. 1 tall sweet-smelling indian plant. 2 hist. Perfumed ointment formerly made from this. [medieval latin spica nardi]

Dishonour  (us dishonor) —n. 1 loss of honour or respect; disgrace. 2 thing causing this. —v. 1 disgrace (dishonoured his name). 2 refuse to accept or pay (a cheque etc.).

Repercussion  n. 1 indirect effect or reaction following an event or act. 2 recoil after impact. 3 echo. [latin: related to *re-]

Undone  adj. 1 not done. 2 not fastened. 3 archaic ruined.

-ary  suffix forming adjectives (contrary; primary). [french -aire, latin -ari(u)s]

Stonemason  n. Person who cuts, prepares, and builds with stone.

Contradict  v. 1 deny (a statement). 2 deny a statement made by (a person). 3 be in opposition to or in conflict with.  contradiction n. Contradictory adj. [latin dico dict- say]

Poultry  n. Domestic fowls (ducks, geese, turkeys, chickens, etc.), esp. As a source of food. [french: related to *poult]

Slovenly  —adj. Careless and untidy; unmethodical. —adv. In a slovenly manner.  slovenliness n.

Moot  —adj. Debatable, undecided (moot point). —v. Raise (a question) for discussion. —n. Hist. Assembly. [old english]

Fusion  n. 1 fusing or melting. 2 blending. 3 coalition. 4 = *nuclear fusion. [latin: related to *fuse1]

Balaclava  n. (in full balaclava helmet) usu. Woollen covering for the whole head and neck, except for the face. [balaclava in the crimea, the site of a battle in 1854]

Analogize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) use, or represent or explain by, analogy.

Unimaginative  adj. Lacking imagination; stolid, dull.  unimaginatively adv.

Oversize  adj. (also -sized) of greater than the usual size.

Plunger  n. 1 part of a mechanism that works with a plunging or thrusting movement. 2 rubber cup on a handle for clearing blocked pipes by a plunging and sucking action.

Stability  n. Being stable. [latin: related to *stable]

Face  —n. 1 front of the head from forehead to chin. 2 facial expression. 3 coolness, effrontery. 4 surface, esp.: a the side of a mountain etc. (north face). B = *coalface. C geom. Each surface of a solid. D the façade of a building. E the dial of a clock etc. 5 functional side of a tool etc. 6 = *typeface. 7 aspect (unacceptable face of capitalism). —v. (-cing) 1 look or be positioned towards or in a certain direction. 2 be opposite. 3 meet resolutely. 4 confront (faces us with a problem). 5 a coat the surface of (a thing). B put a facing on (a garment).  face the music colloq. Take unpleasant consequences without flinching. Face up to accept bravely. Have the face be shameless enough. In face (or the face) of despite. Lose face be humiliated. On the face of it apparently. Put a bold (or brave) face on it accept difficulty etc. Cheerfully. Save face avoid humiliation. Set one's face against oppose stubbornly. To a person's face openly in a person's presence. [latin facies]

Downcast  adj. 1 dejected. 2 (of eyes) looking downwards.

Electioneer  v. Take part in an election campaign.

Specialize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) 1 (often foll. By in) a be or become a specialist. B devote oneself to an interest, skill, etc. (specializes in insulting people). 2 (esp. In passive) adapt for a particular purpose (specialized organs). 3 (as specialized adj.) Of a specialist (specialized work).  specialization n. [french: related to *special]

Trousers  n.pl. 1 two-legged outer garment reaching from the waist usu. To the ankles. 2 (trouser) (attrib.) Designating part of this (trouser leg).  wear the trousers (esp. Of a wife) dominate in a marriage.  trousered adj. [in pl. After drawers: irish and gaelic triubhas trews]

Fodder  n. Dried hay or straw etc. As animal food. [old english]

Evacuee  n. Person evacuated.

Preface  —n. 1 introduction to a book stating its subject, scope, etc. 2 preliminary part of a speech. —v. (-cing) 1 (foll. By with) introduce or begin (a speech or event). 2 provide (a book etc.) With a preface. 3 (of an event etc.) Lead up to (another).  prefatory adj. [latin praefatio]

Revd  abbr. Reverend.

Obscure  —adj. 1 not clearly expressed or easily understood. 2 unexplained. 3 dark. 4 indistinct. 5 hidden; unnoticed. 6 (of a person) undistinguished, hardly known. —v. (-ring) 1 make obscure or unintelligible. 2 conceal.  obscurity n. [french from latin]

Hypnotize  v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing) 1 produce hypnosis in. 2 fascinate; capture the mind of.

Aquarius  n. (pl. -es) 1 constellation and eleventh sign of the zodiac (the water-carrier). 2 person born when the sun is in this sign. [latin: related to *aquarium]

Wickerwork  n. 1 wicker. 2 things made of wicker.

Frenzy  —n. (pl. -ies) wild or delirious excitement, agitation, or fury. —v. (-ies, -ied) (usu. As frenzied adj.) Drive to frenzy.  frenziedly adv. [medieval latin: related to *frenetic]

Savoy  n. Cabbage with wrinkled leaves. [savoy in se france]

Commonplace  —adj. Lacking originality; trite; ordinary. —n. 1 event, topic, etc. That is ordinary or usual. 2 trite remark. [translation of latin locus communis]

Moorland  n. Extensive area of moor.

Gratitude  n. Being thankful; readiness to return kindness. [latin: related to *grateful]

Undervest  n. Vest.

Circum-  comb. Form round, about. [latin]

Harangue  —n. Lengthy and earnest speech. —v. (-guing) make a harangue to; lecture. [french arenge from medieval latin]

Coventry  n.  send a person to coventry refuse to associate with or speak to a person. [coventry in england]

Abuzz  adv. & adj. In a state of excitement or activity.

Killjoy  n. Gloomy or censorious person, esp. At a party etc.

Contumacious  adj. Stubbornly or wilfully disobedient.  contumacy n. (pl. -ies). [latin tumeo swell]

Jacobean  —adj. 1 of the reign of james i. 2 (of furniture) heavy and dark in style. —n. Jacobean person. [latin jacobus james]

Arbiter  n. 1 arbitrator in a dispute. 2 person influential in a specific field (arbiter of taste). [latin from arbitror to judge]

Transitive  adj. (of a verb) taking a direct object (whether expressed or implied), e.g. Saw in saw the donkey, saw that she was ill. [latin: related to *transit]

Pragmatic  adj. Dealing with matters from a practical point of view.   pragmatically adv. [greek pragma -mat- deed]

Clunk  —n. Dull sound as of thick pieces of metal meeting. —v. Make such a sound. [imitative]

Commingle  v. (-ling) literary mingle together.

Caramel  n. 1 a burnt sugar or syrup as a flavouring or colouring. B a kind of soft toffee. 2 light-brown colour.  caramelize v. (also -ise) (-zing or -sing). [french from spanish]

Medusa  n. (pl. Medusae or -s) jellyfish. [greek medousa, name of a gorgon]

Pottery  n. (pl. -ies) 1 vessels etc. Made of fired clay. 2 potter's work. 3 potter's workshop. [french: related to *potter2]

Videodisc  n. Disc for recording moving pictures and sound.

Telephone  —n. 1 apparatus for transmitting sound (esp. Speech) to a distance, esp. By using optical or electrical signals. 2 handset etc. Used in this. 3 system of communication using a network of telephones. —v. (-ning) 1 speak to or send (a message) by telephone. 2 make a telephone call.  on the telephone having or using a telephone. Over the telephone using the telephone.  telephonic adj. Telephonically adv.

Partition  —n. 1 structure dividing a space, esp. A light interior wall. 2 division into parts, esp. Polit. Of a country. —v. 1 divide into parts. 2 (foll. By off) separate (part of a room etc.) With a partition. [latin partior divide]

Miniature  —adj. 1 much smaller than normal. 2 represented on a small scale. —n. 1 any miniature object. 2 detailed small-scale portrait. 3 this genre.  in miniature on a small scale.  miniaturist n. (in senses 2 and 3 of n.). [latin minium red lead]

Famous  adj. 1 (often foll. By for) celebrated; well-known. 2 colloq. Excellent.  famously adv. [latin: related to *fame]

Hammerhead  n. Shark with a flattened head and with eyes in lateral extensions of it.

Brahma  n. 1 hindu creator. 2 supreme divine hindu reality. [sanskrit, = creator]

Uncompleted  adj. Not completed; incomplete.

Bushfire  n. Forest or scrub fire often spreading widely.

Compass  n. 1 instrument showing the direction of magnetic north and bearings from it. 2 (usu. In pl.) Instrument for taking measurements and describing circles, with two arms connected at one end by a hinge. 3 circumference or boundary. 4 area, extent; scope; range. [latin passus pace]

Cincture  n. Literary girdle, belt, or border. [latin cingo gird]

Rave  —v. (-ving) 1 talk wildly or furiously in or as in delirium. 2 (usu. Foll. By about, over) speak with rapturous admiration; go into raptures. 3 colloq. Enjoy oneself freely (esp. Rave it up). —n. 1 (usu. Attrib.) Colloq. Highly enthusiastic review. 2 (also rave-up) colloq. Lively party. 3 slang craze. [probably french dial. Raver]

Conformation  n. Way a thing is formed; shape.

Valid  adj. 1 (of a reason, objection, etc.) Sound, defensible. 2 a executed with the proper formalities, legally acceptable (valid contract; valid passport). B not yet expired.  validity n. [latin validus strong: related to *valiant]

Fledgling  n. (also fledgeling) 1 young bird. 2 inexperienced person.

Difference  n. 1 being different or unlike. 2 degree of this. 3 way in which things differ. 4 a quantity by which amounts differ. B remainder left after subtraction. 5 disagreement, dispute.  make a (or all the, no, etc.) Difference have a significant (or a very significant, or no etc.) Effect. With a difference having a new or unusual feature.

Disconsolate  adj. Forlorn, unhappy, disappointed.  disconsolately adv. [latin: related to *dis-, *solace]

Cupid  n. 1 roman god of love, represented as a naked winged boy archer. 2 (also cupid) representation of cupid. [latin cupio desire]

Ideal  —adj. 1 answering to one's highest conception; perfect. 2 existing only in idea; visionary. —n. Perfect type, thing, concept, principle, etc., esp. As a standard to emulate. [french: related to *idea]

Productive  adj. 1 of or engaged in the production of goods. 2 producing much (productive writer). 3 producing commodities of exchangeable value (productive labour). 4 (foll. By of) producing or giving rise to (productive of great annoyance).  productively adv. Productiveness n. [latin: related to *produce]

Apprise  v. (-sing) formal inform. [french appris(e) learnt, taught]

Prelude  —n. (often foll. By to) 1 action, event, or situation serving as an introduction. 2 introductory part of a poem etc. 3 mus. A introductory piece to a fugue, suite, etc. B short piece of a similar type. —v. (-ding) 1 serve as a prelude to. 2 introduce with a prelude. [latin ludo lus- play]

Highness  n. 1 state of being high (highness of taxation). 2 (highness) title used when addressing or referring to a prince or princess (her highness; your royal highness).

Articular  adj. Of a joint or joints. [latin: related to *article]

Supersede  v. (-ding) 1 take the place of. 2 replace with another person or thing.  supersession n. [latin supersedeo]

Efficient  adj. 1 productive with minimum waste or effort. 2 (of a person) capable; acting effectively.  efficiency n. Efficiently adv. [latin facio make]

Scraping  n. (esp. In pl.) Fragment produced by scraping.

Humanly  adv. 1 by human means (if it is humanly possible). 2 in a human manner.

Soapwort  n. Plant with pink or white flowers, and leaves yielding a soapy substance.

Biochemistry  n. The study of the chemistry of living organisms.  biochemical adj. Biochemist n.

Introduction  n. 1 introducing or being introduced. 2 formal presentation of one person to another. 3 explanatory section at the beginning of a book etc. 4 introductory treatise. 5 thing introduced.

Handwriting  n. 1 writing done with a pen, pencil, etc. 2 person's particular style of this.  handwritten adj.

Riverside  n. (often attrib.) Ground along a river-bank.

Mission  n. 1 a task or goal assigned to a person or group. B journey undertaken as part of this. C person's vocation. 2 military or scientific operation or expedition. 3 body of persons sent to conduct negotiations or propagate a religious faith. 4 missionary post. [latin: related to *missile]

Push  —v. 1 exert a force on (a thing) to move it or cause it to move away. 2 exert such a force (do not push against the door). 3 a thrust forward or upward. B (cause to) project (pushes out new roots). 4 move forward or make (one's way) by force or persistence. 5 exert oneself, esp. To surpass others. 6 (often foll. By to, into, or to + infin.) Urge, impel, or press (a person) hard; harass. 7 (often foll.

Whirl  —v. 1 swing round and round; revolve rapidly. 2 (foll. By away) convey or go rapidly in a vehicle etc. 3 send or travel swiftly in an orbit or a curve. 4 (of the brain etc.) Seem to spin round. —n. 1 whirling movement. 2 state of intense activity (the social whirl). 3 state of confusion (in a whirl).  give it a whirl colloq. Attempt it. [old norse, and low german or dutch]

Saxifrage  n. Rock-plant with small white, yellow, or red flowers. [latin saxum rock, frango break]

Milieu  n. (pl. Milieux or -s) person's environment or social surroundings. [french]

Toothy  adj. (-ier, -iest) having large, numerous, or prominent teeth.

Commonalty  n. (pl. -ies) 1 the common people. 2 the general body (esp. Of mankind). [medieval latin: related to *common]

Plainsong  n. Unaccompanied church music sung in unison in medieval modes and in free rhythm corresponding to the accentuation of the words.

Compliant  adj. Obedient; yielding.  compliantly adv.

Blitzkrieg  n. Intense military campaign intended to bring about a swift victory. [german, = lightning war]

Recompense  —v. (-sing) 1 make amends to (a person) or for (a loss etc.). 2 requite; reward or punish (a person or action). —n. 1 reward, requital. 2 retribution. [latin: related to *compensate]

Cretaceous  —adj. 1 of or like chalk. 2 (cretaceous) geol. Of the last period of the mesozoic era, with deposits of chalk. —n. (cretaceous) geol. This era or system. [latin creta chalk]

Hasp  n. Hinged metal clasp fitting over a staple and secured by a padlock. [old english]

Blues  n.pl. 1 (prec. By the) bout of depression. 2 a (prec. By the; often treated as sing.) Melancholic music of black american origin, usu. In a twelve-bar sequence. B (pl. Same) (as sing.) Piece of such music (played a blues).

Pharmacology  n. The study of the action of drugs on the body.  pharmacological adj. Pharmacologist n.

Eta  abbr. Estimated time of arrival.

Victorian  —adj. 1 of the time of queen victoria. 2 prudish; strict. —n. Person of this time.

Veda  n. (in sing. Or pl.) Oldest hindu scriptures.  vedic adj. [sanskrit, = knowledge]

Duplicator  n. Machine for making multiple copies of a text etc.

Apiary  n. (pl. -ies) place where bees are kept.  apiarist n. [latin apis bee]

Askew  —adv. Awry, crookedly. —predic. Adj. Oblique; awry.

Kitten  —n. Young cat, ferret, etc. —v. (of a cat etc.) Give birth (to).  have kittens colloq. Be very upset or anxious. [anglo-french diminutive of chat *cat]
